results.notes: I have located this Medium sized fungi over previous years. It has been almost impossible to collect as it is invariably too deteriorated to collect. However on this occasion I was lucky enough to save one specimen. (Now dried). Spore print Brown, and Stipe Very Shallow rooted. I have shown an included image depicting the short amount of contact with the forest soil and the base of the stipe. Also rolled over the area where the fungi was rooted. I imagine it is a Boletus, but never able to get an ID. Cap uneven.
results.location_name: Yarrahapinni State Forest, North of Grassy Head, New South Wales, Australia

results.notes: This Fungi although similar to MO Obs:Observation 226638: Fungi Bartl. was found in similar ground conditions Shallow rooted in Rainforest floor, but loaded individually. results.notes:
Parasitic on Acarospora (observation 224867).

Endococcus stigma is a lichenicolous fungi that is parasitic on Acarospora subgenus Phaeothallia, and seems to be the closest ID I can get at this time.

Pseudothecia is black, deeply immersed in thallus. Asci narrowly clavate. Ascoscpores uniseriate, 8 per ascus. Spores 1-septate, constricted at the septum, oblong, brown.

A few spore measurements are:
14.75 × 7.3 µm
15.3 × 7.6 µm
17.0 × 7.3 µm
16.4 × 9.8 µm
15.35 × 7.75 µm

results.notes: A very typical local P. chrysophaeus. I’m posting this to illustrate the “standard” variety of the species in our area. Pileipellis cross-section shows the layered distribution of brown and yellow pigments and the shape of the elements.
results.location_name: Akademgorodok, Novosibirsk, Russia

results.notes: A Pluteus sect. Celluloderma which is much less common in our area than P. chrysophaeus (and probably mistaken for it). It differs in much brighter pileus colors with no brown hues whatsoever and golden yellow stipe (not white). I’m attaching a cross-section of the pileus to show the inflated element shape and pigment distribution, which differ from the true P. chrysophaeus in being much brighter and narrower, without any traces of brown pigment (cf. http://mushroomobserver.org/226668 )
results.location_name: Akademgorodok, Novosibirsk, Russia

results.notes: A typical local “P. plautus”.
results.location_name: Akademgorodok, Novosibirsk, Russia

results.location_name: Akademgorodok, Novosibirsk, Russia

results.notes: Large group (about 25) found fruiting in pine litter and mulch beneath white pines. Despite temperatures in the 30s and close to 8" of rain a couple of days before they looked quite fresh. The following day part of this area was covered with Meramec River flooding in my area. The largest caps were about 15 cm. and the smallest 6 cm. Short, thick stalks. A couple of the smaller ones had inrolled cap margins. Heavy and water soaked. Kuo describes this species as having copious basal mycelium and the gills separable from the cap as a layer. This characteristic was observed.
results.location_name: Southwest St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes:
IN PROGRESS:

Habitat: Under mature Short-needled Pine

Smell: Woodsy-spicey, mild.
Taste: used tip of tongue to taste cut edge with milk, immediate almost no taste. After several minutes an acrid taste developed, not strong but persistent, lingering even after washing out my mouth and gargling, made my throat sore.

Milk: developed immediately to slightest touch, immediately yellow as shown in photos. No more color changes. When flesh was broken, the same yellow color developed around margens of flesh ( shown in some photos).

Spore Print: off-white – need to check in better light

Spore Microscopy: TBD

Cap: Maximum size: 3 inches across. see photos. Moderately brittle, not quite so much as Russula.

Gills: see photos

Stipe: rooted.
results.location_name: Macedonia Cemetery, Marion Co., Texas, USA

results.notes:
Code: Bot_465/2010_IMG2775

Habitat: mixed wood, Picea abies and Fagus Sylvatica dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, south aspect; calcareous ground; in shade, relatively warm place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6-7 deg C, elevation 1.000 m (3.300 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: short, highly disintegrated and moss overgrown log of Picea abies lying on ground.

results.notes:

results.notes:
Typical A. tabescens in Florida during my visit. They look like lawn ornaments all over Polk county. Seldom are they found at the base of trees as they are in Maryland and Virginia. While it is reasonable to suspect these are growing on buried wood, the prevalence of fb’s in lawns suggest to me that there is another variety or species here, although of course, it may just be the environmental conditions at work on the same one!

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 145978006 on January 6, 2023.

results.notes:
Small terrestrial gilled fungi
-Cap 8mm-16mm
-Light brown, convex w/ darker umbo, striate margin
-Gills off white, attached
-Stipe 1 mm thick, 2-3 cm long, twisting and fibrous, hollow. Straw color over white base color
-Smell: fruity, cucumber but not pleasant
-Taste: like watermelon rind
-Spores: white print, ovoid 5×7um, weakly amyloid
-Ecology: on ground with pine and oak

results.notes:
Large terrestrial gilled fungi
-Cap 7-8cm reddish brown center fading to brown outter edge. Flattened w/ depressed center. Cap surface mottled with compressed fibrils.
-Gill: close attached and slightly notched. choc brown color
-Stipe 7mm x4 mm. Yellow at apex becoming brown at base
-Ecology: On ground, buried deep in pine needles. Unclear what it was growing on…presuming buried wood (but could be pine or oak).
-Spore: elliptical 5×7.5um smooth print deep purple

results.notes: A pair fruiting in grass under Pin Oak in record-setting wet conditions (11 inches of rain in the two days prior). Largest cap: 3 cm., dark chocolate brown with forked gills. Stem: 2.5 cm. X .5 cm. club shaped. Specimens were entirely drenched and almost flooded out of the ground. In spite of the water, neither cap nor stems were viscid or slimey, just wet. Although the pouring rain made detection of a cortina difficult, there may be traces on the cap, cap rim, and stem (see photos). Odor very faintly pleasant, although I can not give it a name. Spore print: rusty-brown.

KIWA, Hannover, Niedersachsen, Germany

results.notes:
Code: Bot_465/2010_IMG2787

Habitat: A widening of a dirt forest road lightly overgrown with grasses and other green plants, semi ruderal place of former forestry activities; mountain slope, south aspect; relatively warm place; locally flat, calcareous ground with a lot of half buried and buried Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica thrown away wood pieces; sunny, open place, exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6-7 deg C, elevation 870 m (2.850 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: sand and gravel with buried pieces of wood; most probably on Picea abies.

Place: South slopes of Mt. Kanin mountain group west of Bovec, lower Gozdec place, next to the dirt road from Bovec to Cable car Kanin station B Čela, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: This find shows rather old fruitbodies being unusual regarding their habitat. Several tens of mushrooms were growing virtually on sandy and stony flat surface of a dirt road side. However, closer inspection showed that the ground is full of buried wood, most probably of Picea abies. Mushrooms were growing in several dense, tufted groups of several fruit bodies; pileus diameter about 5 (7) cm; taste unpleasant, smell faint, indistinctive; SP abundant, whitish.

Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5
results.location_name: Kanin Mountain Group, Southwest Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
- Num terreno aberto, com muita erva e alguma vegetação rasteira e poucas árvores de fruto. Algum material lenhoso em decomposição. Pasto caprino e ovino ocasioniais.
- esporada ocre clara
- reacção efeverscente com NH4OH 25% negativa (teste para Conocybe)
- pleurocistidios não encontrados ou de forma e dimensão muito parecida com basidios.
- cheilocystidios aparentemente hialinos em koh8%, clavados, sub capitados
- basidios aparentemente tetrasporicos, pelo menos algumas vezes, de conteúdo mais escuro visível em koh8%
- pilleipelis não celular; cutis filamentosa, hifas horizontais paralelas (incompatível com Conocybe e Pholiotina).

results.notes:
Specimens collected from under an oak, possibly Tanoak. Specimens formed a definite ring around the oak along with a multitude of Suillus fuscomentosus.

Cap: Wine red stains to lobster pink striations across cap with darker center. “Meat” of cap white. Cap planar to depressed in age, texture firm, crisp. Cap viscous when young as shown by extensive detritus stuck to cap. Cap diameter 8-15 cm.

Gills: White with pink to wine red stains along exposed edges, crowded, adnate to decurrent with age.

Stipe: White with same wine red to pinkish tint, tapers downward. Length 8-12 cm , width 2-3.2 cm. Stipe solid with with some pinkish tint inside; no bruising or discoloration when handled.

Odor: None when raw, but definite COCONUT when boiled

results.notes:
Code: Bot_829/2014_DSC3222, Bot_829/2014_DSC3257

Habitat: pasture; moderately inclined mountain slope, grassland; southeast aspect; shallow, calcareous ground; open, rather dry and sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, ‘Na Melu’ pasture near Trenta 2b cottage, on the upper most and the lower part of the pasture; East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: It is interesting to observe how the pilei are changing color with time. Young pilei are almost black tinged deep blue or violet; the gills are initially whitish or lightly bluish. These colors are then gradually changing to more pinkish and finally to brownish colors. One can find quite differently looking pilei next to each other. The gills have characteristic and usually distinctive blue-black edge.

The mushrooms were photographed on two places near each other on the same pasture. They were growing solitary and in scattered groups of several fruit bodies. There were about 20 of them all together. Pilei diameter from 20 to 35(48) mm, stipe from 6 to 11 cm long and from 2 to 3.5 mm in diameter; flesh brittle; stipe fibrous, hollow; SP abundant, pinkish-ochre, oac651.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Specimen, including spore print, is at Ohio University, Athens, Ohio.

Line of mushrooms observed in lawn below spruce trees. Cap light brown, irregular, almost viscid, without fibrils. Gills white on edges, light brown within, free or notched at stipe. Stipe brown below, with white cottony network towards apex, not hollow. Spore print white/cream first night, increasing to buff/light tan during following day. No distinctive smell (other than mushroomy), but specimens had been under snow and were partly frozen when first observed. Best guess is a Tricholoma or possibly a Hygrophorus.

All images taken with iPad mini.

results.notes: Interesting small polypore fruiting along the top and side of a fallen decaying log in Oak-Hickory forest. It begins as an ochraceus/tawny spreading resupinate growth and organizes itself into distinct overlapping and laterally fused caps. Larger caps: 2.8 cm. wide X 1.7 cm. deep X 6 mm. thick at point of attachment; very rubbery, pliable, short appressed hairs on cap surface. Non-fertile and fertile surfaces, as well as context, are ochraceus/tawny. Large (1/mm.) angular and round pores. No detectable odor. KOH negative on all surfaces. Spore print pending.

results.notes:
Seen at the Santa Cruz Fungus Fair. Very viscid cap which stains reddish in KOH, purple stipe apex, stem also reddish in KOH, mild odor and flavor. The spores are (7.3) 7.5 – 8.0 (8.3) x (4.2) 4.4 – 4.6 (4.8) µm.

Stephanie Jarvis took this collection and used it for one of her talks, then threw it away. It was rescued from the trash by a team of dumpster divers, and is going out on display soon – Hopefully with a better name than Cortinarius sp.

results.notes: Several cespitose clusters in various stages of maturity fruiting from the bottom sides of a fallen, very decayed log where it meets the ground. Oak and Hickory associates. Largest cap: 9 cm.; gills close and forked, attached to slightly decurrent. Stem: 8 cm. X 8 mm., persistent rusty color from superior ring, yellow flesh, white mycelium at base. Spore print: rusty-orange. Older specimens (last photo) are cracked and shriveled.

results.notes:
This is all that remains of a most gangbusters haul from the swollen hills of the Brush Creek Fire of 2007, which netted myself and my ladyfriend roughly $4000-$5000 in Ebay sales by the end of the year (though not before being turned down by every single fine dining establishment in Madison, Wisconsin and Chicago — all visited in person — who would only purchase fresh, not dried). It had apparently dawned on no one but our trusty hillbilly guide, Bill Wild — who subsisted on a diet of Marlboro Reds, Doritos, uncooked Top Ramen and Natural Ice while charging up and down hillsides — that the section of the burn across the river in between the two well-separated bridges would be prime, untouched morelling territory. One scouting mission in a punctured raft, doctored with mailing tape and only good for one crossing before requiring reinflation, proved him right. We camped for eight days, collecting from morning to late afternoon, eating Annie’s soups and sardines in the middle of grizzly country like college kid bear bait, field drying what we could on lengths of window screen stretched taught between downed logs. It would take several more crossings (and much more mailing tape), under cover of near darkness, to “illegally” shuttle those 400lbs back across the river and to the safety of waiting dehydrators in Missoula. We had photo negatives of morels superimposed against the backs of our eyelids and throughout our dreams for weeks on end. Never have I smelled more of mushroom and been so uncleanably caked in soot in my life, nor have I ever come into any patch even remotely close in scale ever since.

These particular fruiting bodies are part of a one ounce bag sold to my good friend and former employer, Jacob Deatherage of Ex Libris Anonymous, and were the occasion of our first meeting. He was more interested in the story behind the mushrooms (hinted at in the Craigslist ad for their sale) than eating them, best evidenced by the fact that he still has a couple left after eight years!

results.notes:
Code: Bot_759/2013_DSC8496

Habitat: grassland, former pasture gradually overgrowing with Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies; flat, calcareous, old alluvial ground; quite in shade; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-7 deg C, elevation 980 m (3.200 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Zadnja Trenta valley, Zapodn place; left bank of dry bed of river Soča; somewhat upstream of the last pastures; East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: From far I thought I found Russula queletii. But totally white stipe, distinctly colored gills and the fact that it had mild taste ruled this option out. Very dense, straw colored, very sparsely branched gills with entire edge, and almost no short gills that extend only part way to stipe, as well as other macroscopic traits and dimensions and surface ornamentation of spores fit well to Russula romellii. However, whenever I call to mind how many species exist in this genus I start to doubt in my determinations.

Growing solitary. Pileus diameter 10.5 cm, SP beige-yellow-ocher, oac 812.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Zadnja Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
Code: Bot_825/2014_DSC2871
Picture file names: from Inocybe-rimosa-var-rimosa_raw_1 to Inocybe-rimosa-var-rimosa_raw_5.

Habitat: bare ground in mixed forest, Picea abies and Fagus sylvatica dominant trees; under a group of large Picea abies; flat, raw humus rich, calcareous ground, old alluvium at the bottom of an alpine valley; in shade; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 4-6 deg C, elevation 985 m (3.250 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil.

Place: Zadnja Trenta valley, ‘Zapodn’ place, upstream from the last farmhouses, left bank of dry river bed of Soča, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comments: With the help of the key given in Krieglsteiner (2010) (Ref.4) even ‘var. rimosa’ was apparently easy to be determined. This name is legitimate according to MycoBank, however, Index Fungorum doesn’t recognize it as a valid name and considers it as a synonym of Inocybe rimosa.

Growing solitary; a single pileus found; cap diameter 5 cm, height 4.2 cm; stipe 12 cm long, 1 cm in diameter, fibrous, not hollow, twisted, and deeply rooted in ground; gills distinctly lemon-yellowish with slight green tint, oac6; after 24 hours being kept in refrigerator pale ocher-brown, oac717; SP pale ocher, oac688.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
